metadata.source: DEM Analysis and Acronym Glossary (Alberta/Canadian Context)
metadata.description: Definition dataset for a matching minigame focusing on Disaster and Emergency Management (DEM), covering acronyms, frameworks, agencies, and core concepts with a focus on Canadian and Albertan legislation and operations.

definitions.definition: The evolution of the field from 'Disaster Management' (reactive response/recovery) to 'Disaster Risk Reduction' (proactive mitigation/prevention). Hazards may be inevitable, but disasters are socially constructed and preventable.
A collaborative network model that rejects government-centric 'Command and Control' in favor of integrating the private sector, NGOs, and individual citizens (partners) into resilience planning.

An operational asset in DEM training. Includes tools like 'Green Zone' leadership and understanding the 'Mental Health Continuum' to maintain cognitive function and decision-making in high-stress environments.
The Canadian legislative structure where emergency capacity scales up from the Individual -> Municipal -> Provincial -> Federal. The province acts as the critical gateway for federal aid requests.
Alberta Emergency Management Agency. The provincial agency responsible for the coordination, collaboration, and oversight of prevention, preparedness, response, and recovery activities in Alberta.
All-Hazards Incident Management Team. A multi-agency team deployed to manage major incidents that extend beyond one operational period.
All-Hazards Risk Assessment. A federal process used by Public Safety Canada to identify and prioritize risks based on their likelihood and impact.
Australasian Inter-service Incident Management System. An incident management framework used primarily in Australia, similar to ICS.
Alberta Incident Management System. The mandated command and control framework for local authorities in Alberta, built upon ICS principles to ensuring interoperability during provincial responses.
Ad Hoc Incident Review. An immediate, informal check-in led by a leader after a stressful event to acknowledge the situation and support the team.
Business Continuity Management. The holistic management process that identifies potential threats to an organization and the impacts to business operations.
Business Continuity Plan. A document outlining how an organization will continue to function during and after an emergency.
Business Impact Analysis. A process to identify and evaluate the potential effects of business interruptions on critical business operations.
Canadian Armed Forces. The military force of Canada, often requested by provinces (via the Federal Government) to assist in large-scale domestic disasters (Operation LENTUS).
Capability Improvement Process. A method used to review government responses to exercises and events to ensure continuous improvement.
Chemical, Biological, Radiological, Nuclear, and Explosives. An acronym used to describe a specific category of intentional or accidental hazards involving these dangerous materials.
Canadian Coast Guard. A federal agency responsible for maritime search and rescue and marine environmental response.
Civil Contingencies Secretariat. The UK government body responsible for emergency planning and resilience (roughly analogous to Public Safety Canada).
Calgary Emergency Management Agency. The municipal agency responsible for disaster planning and coordination in the City of Calgary.
Complex Humanitarian Emergency. A humanitarian crisis in a country, region, or society where there is total or considerable breakdown of authority resulting from internal or external conflict.
Critical Infrastructure. Processes, systems, facilities, technologies, networks, assets, and services essential to the health, safety, security, or economic well-being of Canadians.
Continuous Improvement of Federal Event Response. A program within the Government Operations Centre to track strategic recommendations from after-action reports.
Critical Incident Stress Debriefing. A specific, 7-phase group crisis intervention tool designed to mitigate acute stress in emergency responders; it is a component of CISM.
Critical Incident Stress Management. A comprehensive, integrated, multi-component crisis intervention system.
Crisis Management Team. A team designated to handle the reputational and strategic aspects of a crisis for an organization.
Continuity of Operations Plan. Similar to a BCP, focusing on restoring essential functions of an organization (often used in government contexts).
Common Operating Picture. A single display of relevant information (operational status, resources, situation) shared by more than one command/coordination center to facilitate collaborative planning.
Crime Prevention Through Environmental Design. A multi-disciplinary approach to deterring criminal behavior through environmental design.
Canadian Standards Association (CSA Group). A non-profit organization that develops standards, including CSA Z1600 (Emergency and Continuity Management Program).
Cascadia Subduction Zone. A major geological fault line off the coast of British Columbia capable of producing catastrophic earthquakes and tsunamis.

Director of Emergency Management. The individual appointed by a local authority (municipality) in Alberta to direct and control emergency response. Also refers to Disaster and Emergency Management as a field.
Disasters and Emergencies Preparedness Programme. An international program (UK-funded) aimed at strengthening humanitarian capacity at the local level.
Disaster Financial Assistance. Provincial programs that provide financial assistance for uninsurable loss and damage caused by disasters.

Disaster Financial Assistance Arrangements. The federal program that provides financial assistance to provinces and territories when response and recovery costs exceed what individual provinces/territories could reasonably be expected to bear.
Department of Homeland Security. The US federal executive department responsible for public security.
Disaster Management. The operational activities associated with the response and recovery phases of a disaster.
Disaster Risk Reduction. The systematic approach to identifying, assessing, and reducing the risks of disaster.
Euro-Atlantic Disaster Response Coordination Centre. NATOâ€™s principal civil emergency response mechanism.
Ecosystem-based Adaptation. The use of biodiversity and ecosystem services to adapt to the adverse effects of climate change.
Emergency Coordination Centre. A facility used to coordinate the response to an emergency; synonymous with EOC in many Alberta jurisdictions.
Ecosystem-based Disaster Risk Reduction. The sustainable management, conservation, and restoration of ecosystems to provide services that reduce disaster risk.
Electronic Fund Transfer. A digital movement of money; used by the Red Cross to distribute aid quickly.

Emergency Management. The management of emergencies concerning all hazards, including all activities and risk management measures related to prevention/mitigation, preparedness, response, and recovery.
Emergency Management British Columbia. The provincial emergency management organization for BC (now Ministry of Emergency Management and Climate Readiness).
Emergency Measures Organization. A generic term (often historical) for the agency responsible for emergency planning.
Emergency Medical Services. Services that provide out-of-hospital acute medical care and transport.
Emergency Operations Centre. A designated facility where the 'coordination' and 'support' functions of a response are carried out (as opposed to tactical command at the scene).
Emergency Operations Plan. A written plan describing the organizational structure, roles, and responsibilities for emergency response.
Enterprise Risk Management. A framework for managing organizational risk that looks at all risks (financial, strategic, hazard) that could stop an organization from achieving its mission.

Emergency Support Function. A grouping of government and private-sector capabilities into an organizational structure to provide the support, resources, and services most likely to be needed to save lives (e.g., ESF-1 Transportation).
Emergency Social Services. A planned emergency response organization designed to provide basic services (food, lodging, clothing) to people affected by a disaster.
Federal Disaster Assistance Initiative. A Canadian federal initiative to create an inventory of programs to aid disaster recovery.
Federal Emergency Management Agency. The US agency responsible for coordinating the response to disasters that overwhelm the resources of local and state authorities.
Federal Emergency Response Plan. The Government of Canada's 'all-hazards' emergency response plan.
Firefighting Resources of Southern California Organized for Potential Emergencies. The group that originally developed the Incident Command System (ICS).
Federal, Provincial, and Territorial. Refers to the three orders of government in Canada working together.

Gender-Based Analysis Plus. An analytical process used by the Government of Canada to assess how different groups of women, men, and gender-diverse people may experience policies, programs, and initiatives.
Government Operations Centre. The principal means by which Public Safety Canada provides strategic-level coordination on behalf of the Government of Canada during national events.
Hazardous Materials. Substances that pose a significant risk to health, safety, or property.
Hyogo Framework for Action. The UN framework for disaster risk reduction that preceded the Sendai Framework (2005-2015).
Hazard Information Profiles. Tools that describe hazard types based on global scientific research.
Hazard, Risk & Vulnerability Analysis. A process used to identify threats, assess the risk they pose, and determine the community's vulnerability to them.
Homeland Security Presidential Directive. Directives issued by the US President on matters of national security (e.g., HSPD-5).
Heavy Urban Search and Rescue. Specialized teams capable of searching for and rescuing victims trapped in collapsed structures.
International Association of Emergency Managers. A non-profit educational organization dedicated to promoting the 'Principles of Emergency Management'.
Incident Action Plan. A written or verbal plan that reflects the incident objectives, strategies, and tactics for a specific operational period.
Incident Commander. The individual responsible for all incident activities, including the development of strategies and tactics and the ordering and release of resources.
Incident Command Post. The field location at which the primary tactical-level, on-scene incident command functions are performed.

Incident Command System. A standardized on-site management system designed to enable effective and efficient incident management by integrating facilities, equipment, personnel, procedures, and communications operating within a common organizational structure.
International Decade for Natural Disaster Reduction. A UN initiative (1990-1999) to reduce the impact of natural disasters.
International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies. A global humanitarian organization.
Incident Management System. A broad term for the operational framework used for emergency response (includes ICS, AIIMS, etc.).
Integrated National Security Enforcement Team. RCMP-led teams that investigate national security threats and terrorism.
Indigenous Services Canada. The federal department that supports First Nations communities, including funding and support for emergency management.
International Organization for Standardization. An independent, non-governmental international organization that develops voluntary standards (e.g., ISO 22301 for Business Continuity).
Interagency Task Force. A team convened to solve complex problems that span more than one Emergency Support Function.
Joint Information Center. A facility established to coordinate all incident-related public information activities.
Local Authority Emergency Management Regulation. Alberta regulation that mandates the use of AIMS and outlines the duties of local authorities.
Multi-Agency Coordination. A system used to coordinate resources and support between agencies or jurisdictions (strategic level) as opposed to Incident Command (tactical level).
Municipal Emergency Plan. The emergency plan required by legislation for all municipalities in Canada.
Mental Health and Psychosocial Support. A term used in the humanitarian sector to describe support for mental health and social well-being.
Memorandum of Understanding. A formal agreement between two or more parties (often used for Mutual Aid Agreements).
North Atlantic Treaty Organization. An intergovernmental military alliance.
National Business Emergency Operations Center. A US FEMA initiative to coordinate with the private sector.
National Disaster Recovery Framework. A US framework that guides recovery efforts.
National Emergency Response System. The framework that allows for the harmonization of joint federal, provincial, and territorial response to emergencies in Canada.
National Fire Protection Association. A US trade association that creates standards (e.g., NFPA 1600) adopted by many Canadian jurisdictions.
Non-Governmental Organization. A non-profit organization that operates independently of any government.
National Incident Management System. The US comprehensive national approach to incident management (of which ICS is a component).
National Public Alerting System. Canada's system for emergency alerts (Alert Ready).
Non-Profit Organization. An organization that does not distribute its surplus funds to owners or shareholders.
Natural Resources Canada. The federal department responsible for natural resources, explosives, and natural hazards (earthquakes, space weather).
National Response Plan. The predecessor to the US National Response Framework.
Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs. A UN body responsible for bringing together humanitarian actors to ensure a coherent response to emergencies.
Office of Critical Infrastructure Protection and Emergency Preparedness. A historical Canadian federal body (pre-Public Safety Canada).
Occupational Health and Safety. Laws and regulations protecting the safety of workers.
Occupational Safety and Health Administration. The US agency responsible for worker safety.
Plan-Do-Check-Act. An iterative four-step management method used for the control and continuous improvement of processes (used in CSA Z1600).
Partnership for Environment and Disaster Risk Reduction. A global partnership promoting ecosystem-based DRR.
Psychological First Aid. A humane, supportive response to a fellow human being who is suffering and may need support.
Public Information Officer. The individual responsible for interfacing with the public and media and/or with other agencies with incident-related information requirements.
Personal Protective Equipment. Equipment worn to minimize exposure to hazards (also used metaphorically as 'Psychological PPE').
Public Safety Canada. The federal department responsible for protecting Canadians and helping to maintain a peaceful and safe society; the lead for federal EM.
Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder. A mental health condition triggered by a terrifying event.
Provincial/Territorial. Refers to the provinces and territories of Canada.
Road to Mental Resilience. A training program developed by the Department of National Defence and adapted by the Mental Health Commission of Canada.
Royal Canadian Mounted Police. Canada's national police service.
Search and Rescue. The search for and provision of aid to people who are in distress or imminent danger.
Sustainable Development Goals. A set of 17 global goals adopted by the UN in 2015.
State of Local Emergency. A declaration by a local authority (municipality) in Alberta that grants extraordinary powers to deal with an emergency.
Senior Officials Responsible for Emergency Management. A federal/provincial/territorial body in Canada that coordinates EM initiatives.
Stakeholder Preparedness Review. A US FEMA process to assess a community's capability levels.
Threat and Hazard Identification and Risk Assessment. A risk assessment process used (primarily in the US, but concepts applied in Canada) to identify risks and capability targets.
Toxic Industrial Materials. Industrial chemicals that are toxic but are produced in large quantities for industrial use (distinct from chemical weapons).
Unified Command. An ICS application used when more than one agency has incident jurisdiction or when incidents cross political jurisdictions.
United Nations.
United Nations Disaster Assessment & Coordination. A system designed to help the UN and governments of disaster-affected countries during the first phase of a sudden-onset emergency.
United Nations Office for Disaster Risk Reduction. The UN focal point for disaster risk reduction (formerly UNISDR).
United Nations Disaster Relief Office. A historical UN body (1971) created to coordinate disaster relief.
United Nations International Strategy for Disaster Reduction. The previous name for UNDRR.
Urban Search and Rescue. Specialized capabilities to locate, extricate, and medically stabilize victims trapped in confined spaces/collapsed structures.
Water, Sanitation and Hygiene. A key area of humanitarian aid focused on public health.
